choices.text: Burrows are present mainly in Stratum Corneum
Itching Worsens in the Night
Animal Scabies is characterized by Burrows
5% Permethrin Cream from Neck to Toe in Adults & from Head to Toe in Children is Topical Agent of Choice

questions.text: All the statements are true about scabies EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Animal Scabies is characterised by Burrows.

 

Option C. Burrows are absent in animal scabies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A:

 

  • Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptesscabei var hominis / Itch mite / Sarcoptesscabei

 

 

  • The incubation period of Scabies is 3-4 weeks (21-28 days)
  • However, Reinfection of a previously cured individual may provoke immediate symptoms.
  • Burrows in scabies are typically found in the stratum corneum as depicted in the below image.

 

 

  • In most people the trails of the burrowing mites appear brownish linear or s shaped tracks in the skin & occur as a result of excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis.
  • S shaped track, pointed with black arrows in the below image.

 

 

  • Lesions are found in the Circle of Hebra (imaginary line formed by connecting the sites of involvement in scabies like, web spaces, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, cack, breasts, buttocks & external genitals).

 

Option B:

 

  • Itching worsens at night & when the patient is warm. Nocturnal pruritus is the most common symptom associated with scabies.
  • Water-washed diseases, such as scabies, are infections brought on by poor personal hygiene and a lack of access to clean water.
  • The distinctive signs include intense itching and shallow burrows.

 

Option D:

 

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults & from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) & pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While human scabies involves burrow formation in the skin, animal scabies does not typically lead to burrow formation when transmitted to humans.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47

questions.text: Causative Agent & Drug of Choice for the condition shown below would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostomabraziliense, Albendazole.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The serpiginous / serpent-like skin lesions seen are cutaneous larva migrans or larva currens.
  • The hookworms Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are the least likely to result in cutaneous larva migrans in humans.
  • Non-human hookworms like Ancylostomabraziliense and Ancylostoma caninum that are acquired through direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat faeces are the cause of cutaneous larva migrans.
  • It is common after visiting tropical or endemic regions, and symptoms usually appear within the first two weeks.
  • First line treatment: oral ivermectin at 200 microgram/kg or albendazole.
  • An inflamed papule, frequently found in the space between the toes, indicates the point of entry. Later, as the larvae migrate through the epidermis, serpentine or linear single-track lines become visible. The growth of the lesions can reach 1 to 2 cm per day.

 

 

Larva Currens Skin Lesions

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous larva migrans, presenting with serpiginous skin lesions, is commonly caused by Ancylostomabraziliense, and the treatment of choice is Albendazole.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4. Page No 4.13-14

questions.text: Chiclero ulcer /Gum tree harvester’s ulcer is caused by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leishmania Mexicana.

 

Option C.

 

  • Chiclero Ulcer: New world leishmaniasis /Gum tree harvester’s ulcer is caused by Leishmania Mexicana (New world Leishmaniasis).
  • The Lutzomyia sandfly, the vector, bites chicle collectors, causing lesions on the side of the face or behind ears.
  • The pinna of the ear can be destroyed by lesions on the pinna that may invade cartilage and take a long time to heal.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enterobius vermicularis:

 

  • Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as the pinworm, is a nematode parasite that causes enterobiasis, primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract, particularly the anus and rectum, and does not cause ulcers.
  • Most frequent in children associated with nocturnal pruritus ani.

 

Option B. Ancylostomabraziliense:

 

  • Ancylostomabraziliense is a species of hookworm that can cause cutaneous larva migrans, presenting as serpiginous skin lesions, not ulcers.

 

Option D. Strongyloides stercoralis:

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is an intestinal roundworm that causes strongyloidiasis, which can lead to severe systemic infection, especially in immunocompromised hosts, but is not associated with Chiclero’s ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chiclero’s ulcer, also known as Gum tree harvester’s ulcer, is caused by Leishmania Mexicana, which is transmitted by the bite of an infected sandfly.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 Page No 33.47

questions.text: Maculae Ceruleae are seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pthirus Pubis.

 

Option C: Pthirus pubis / Pediculosis pubis caused by Crab Louse (image below)

 

 

  • Blue grey macule at the site of pubic lice bite is seen known as Maculae ceruleae.
  • Maculae ceruleae mark the hemosiderin-stained purpuric spots where lice have fed.
  • Pthirus pubis Causes infestation of pubic area, axillae & eyelashes.
  • It is a Sexually transmitted disease.
  • The image given below shows pediculosis pubis countless white spots & lice in pubic hairs.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pediculosis capitis:

 

  • Pediculosis capitis, or head lice infestation, does not typically present with maculae ceruleae.
  • The primary symptom is itching of the scalp, and the findings include lice and nits (lice eggs) on the hair and scalp.

 

Option B. Pediculosis corporis:

 

  • Pediculosis corporis, or body lice infestation, is characterized by itching, especially along the seams of clothing where lice tend to reside.
  • Maculae ceruleae are not a characteristic finding in this condition.

 

Option D. Scabies:

 

  • Scabies, caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, presents with intense itching, especially at night, and a rash that includes burrows but not maculae ceruleae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Maculae Ceruleae, Bluish-Gray Skin Macules, are characteristic of an infestation with Pthirus pubis, the pubic louse.
  • These macules are a result of louse feeding and are not seen in other common parasitic infestations like pediculosis capitis, pediculosis corporis, or scabies.

 

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/pubic-lice

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.21- 34.22

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 19th Edition Page No 2746

Andrew’s Diseases of the Skin Clinical Dermatology – 12th Edition Page No 441

Online resources: https://dermnetnz.org/topics/pubic-licehttps://www.cdc.gov/parasites/lice/pubic/index.html

questions.text: An 8-month-old child presented with itchy exudative papulovesicular lesions on face, palms, soles. Father of the child also has similar complaints associated with nocturnal itching. A diagnosis of scabies is made. In this disease, what part of the baby’s body can be affected, but is UNLIKELY to show lesions in the father?
questions.solution:
Ans.D) Face.

 

Explanation: 

 

  • Multiple itchy eczematous exudative papulovesicular lesions in the face palms soles & trunk are characteristic of infantile scabies.
  • Mites prefer HAIRY skin & areas of low sebum production, so Face, Palms, soles are spared in adults but characteristically involved in infants.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scabies in infants can present with lesions on the face, palms, and soles, which are areas less commonly affected in adults.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.40

choices.text: Number of Lesions correspond to Number of Mites
50% Topical Permethrin is used for treatment
Ivermectin is an Oral Medication used in the treatment
Lesions in Nodular Scabies are not Pruritic

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE about Scabies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin is an Oral Medication used in the Treatment.

 

Option. C: Ivermectin is the only oral medication that can be used in the treatment of scabies.

 

Topical Formulations:

 

  • 5% Permethrin
  • Gamma Benzene Hexachloride
  • Lindane
  • Crotamiton

 

  • Many parasites, including mites, have neurotransmission induced by gamma amino butyric acid that is disrupted by oral ivermectin.
  • Patients over the age of two and weighing more than 15 kg receive a single 200 mcg/kg dose.
  • A second dose is required 7–14 days later because the medication has no ovicidal effect.
  • Invertebrate nerve synapses that use glutamate or gamma aminobutyric acid GABA are blocked by oral ivermectin, which causes the mite to become paralysed and die.
  • It is not indicated in infants & pregnant women
  • To prevent reinfection, this condition needs to be treated simultaneously in all family members, even those who are asymptomatic, and the clothing needs to be disinfected at the same time.
  • It manifests as a few violaceous, itchy nodules that are frequently found on the male genitalia, groin & axillae.
  • They signify an inflammatory response to mite antigens. After anti-scabies treatment, these nodules continue to grow for weeks or months.

 

The below image shows nodular scabies.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A: The number of lesions does not correspond to the number of mites.

 

Option B: Topical 5% permethrin (NOT 50%) is used in the treatment of scabies.

 

Option D: An unusual scabies manifestation is nodular scabies. It is extremely itchy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin is an oral medication used in scabies treatment.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.40 & 34.42

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 3275

questions.text: Most Severe Form of Scabies among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Norwegian Scabies.

 

Option D:

 

  • Norwegian/crusted scabies/Hyperkeratotic scabies: Most severe type, millions of mites present but itching is less / absent.
  • Crusted scabies develops in people who do not have a strong enough immune response to the mite, allowing it to thrive.
  • It is common type of scabies causing institutional breakouts. 
  • Because it was first described in Lepers of Norway, it is known as Norwegian.

 

Norwegian scabies or Human crusted or Hyperkeratotic scabies is seen in:

 

  • Immunocompromised
  • Debilitated patients
  • Neurologic disorders
  • Downs syndrome
  • Organ transplant recipients
  • Hansen’s disease
  • AIDS

 

Clinical images of Norwegian scabies.

 

 

 

Number of mites in scabies patients with normal itch response is 10-15 mites/person.

 

Scabies incognito: Due to Topical Steroid application, clinical picture gets altered.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nodular Scabies:

 

  • While nodular scabies can be persistent and itchy, it is not the most severe form of scabies.
  • Nodular scabies results from a hypersensitivity reaction to the mites and their feces, leading to itchy nodules that may persist even after the mites are eradicated.

 

Option B. Animal Scabies:

 

  • Animal scabies may cause a transient skin reaction in humans after contact with infested animals, but it is not the most severe form as the mites do not reproduce on humans and the condition is self-limiting.

 

Option C. Genital Scabies:

 

  • Genital scabies is a localized infestation of the genital area and, while it may cause significant discomfort, it is not classified as the most severe form of scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most severe form of scabies is Norwegian scabies, which presents with extensive crusting and scaling, and contains a large number of mites, making it highly contagious and severe, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.47

choices.text: It is also called as Pediculosis Capitis
The Causative Organism is a Louse
The Causative Organism is a Vector for Bartonella Quintana
Advice thorough Washing of the Body & Clothes & Application of Permethrin

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding vagabonds disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is also called Pediculosis Capitis.

 

Option A.

 

  • Pediculosis corporis (pediculosis vestimenti or vagabond's disease) is caused by body lice (specifically pediculus corporis)

 

 

  • The disease is known as "vagabonds disease" because it affects the poor, homeless, and wandering (vagabonds) population. The reaction to salivary antigens from louse bites causes itching.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B:  The Causative Organism is a Louse:

 

  • Vagabond's disease is caused by body lice (specifically pediculus corporis)

 

Option C. The causative organism is a vector for Bartonella Quintana:

 

  • The human body louse can transmit Bartonella Quintana, the causative agent of Trench Fever.
  • Important diseases like Relapsing Fever (Borrelia Recurrentis), Trench Fever (Bartonella Quintana), and Epidemic Typhus are spread by Body Lice

 

Option D. Advice thorough washing of the body & clothes & application of permethrin:

 

  • Clothes and Bed Linens should be thoroughly decontaminated.
  • Although this is typically sufficient in most situations, a thorough soap wash followed by the application of pyrethrins, pyrethroids, or malathion for 8–2 hours can also be advised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vagabond's disease is caused by an infestation of body lice, not head lice, and is properly referred to as pediculosis corporis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.21- 34.22

Andrew’s Diseases of the Skin Clinical Dermatology – 12th Edition Page No 437

questions.text: Romana Sign is seen with?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) American trypanosomiasis.

 

Option B. In acute phase shows Unilateral periorbital palpebral painless edema (Romana Sign)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. African Trypanosomiasis: 

 

  • In early phase shows Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy (Winter bottom sign)

 

 

Option C. Leishmania Mexicana:

 

  • Leishmania Mexicana causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, which can present with skin ulcers but not Romana's sign.

 

Option D. Sarcoptes scabiei:

 

  • Sarcoptes scabiei causes scabies, a condition characterized by intense itching and a rash with burrows in the skin, not Romana's sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Romana's sign, characterized by unilateral painless swelling of the eyelids, is seen in American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease) caused by Trypanosoma cruzi.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 Page No 33.39

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with Normo-Anesthetic Hypopigmented Lesions and a History of Prolonged Fever in Childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the Absence of Thickened Nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

 

Option D.

 

  • The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

 

Post- Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis:

 

  • Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

  • The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B

  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.

  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.

  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

  • The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: A 39-year-old man complains of widespread pruritus for the past two weeks. The itching is particularly bad at night. He has no history of note and works in the local car factory. On examination he has noted to have a number of linear erythematous lesions in between his fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scabies.

 

Option B:

 

  • It is a parasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabei Mite.

  • It typically presents with intense itching, especially at night, and can lead to linear erythematous lesions (Burrows) in between the fingers, as well as in other body folds and areas.

 

 

  • Scabies is highly contagious and often spreads through close personal contact.

 

Scabies:

 

  • It burrows into the skin, laying its eggs in the stratum corneum.

 

 

  • The intense pruritus associated with scabies is due to a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction to mites/eggs which occurs about 30 days after the initial infection.

 

Management of Scabies:

 

  • Permethrin 5% is first-line

  • Malathion 0.5% is second-line

  • Pruritus persists for up to 4-6 weeks post-eradication.

 

Option A. Fibreglass exposure

 

  • It is less likely to cause widespread pruritus associated with linear erythematous lesions between the fingers.

  • Exposure to fibreglass can lead to skin irritation and itching, but it is not a common cause of these specific findings.

 

Option C. Cimex lectularius infestation

 

  • Commonly known as bed bugs, can cause skin reactions, including itching and rash.

 

 

  • However, the linear erythematous lesions between the fingers are more characteristic of scabies.

 

Option D. Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • It is a rare disorder that typically presents with bone lesions and is not associated with the clinical findings described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with widespread pruritus, particularly worse at night, and linear erythematous lesions between the fingers (Burrows), the most likely diagnosis is scabies.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.39-34.47

choices.text: 5% Permethrin Below Neck Application
1% Permethrin Whole Body Application

questions.text: What is the Most Effective Treatment of Vagabonds Disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disinfection of Clothing

 

Option C.

 

  • Vagabond's disease, or pediculosis corporis, is best treated by addressing the primary habitat of the lice, which is the clothing.

 

 

  • Disinfection can be achieved by washing clothes in hot water, ironing, or using insecticides specifically for clothing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 5% Permethrin below neck application:

 

  • While permethrin is an effective treatment for lice, 5% permethrin is typically used for the treatment of scabies.
  • For pediculosis corporis (body lice or Vagabond's disease), the concentration used is different, and the focus is on clothing disinfection because body lice live in clothing.

 

Option B. 1% Permethrin whole body application:

 

  • Although 1% permethrin is used for head lice, it is not the most effective treatment for Vagabond's disease, where lice infestation is primarily in the clothes, not on the body itself.

 

Option D. Clotrimazole:

 

  • Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication and would not be effective against lice, as it does not have pediculicidal properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most effective treatment for Vagabond's disease (pediculosis corporis) is disinfection of clothing, as the body louse lives and lays eggs on clothing, not on the body itself.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 34.21

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page No 1511

choices.text: Crush Tissue Preparation Stained with Giemsa
Repeat Slit Smear including Nasal Septum and Earlobes

questions.text: A 53-year-old man from Bihar, India, presents with Multiple Symmetrical, Hypopigmented, Normoanesthetic Macules on his Face, Arms, and Upper Back. He recalls a severe Fever a year prior that required Hospitalization and Injectable Medications. No Nerve Enlargement is observed. A Slit-Skin Smear from the Macules is Negative for Acid-Fast Bacilli. What is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crush Tissue Preparation Stained with Giemsa:

 

Option A: 

 

  • The patient’s clinical presentation and history are suggestive of Post-Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL), which can follow visceral leishmaniasis ("kala-azar").
  • A Giemsa-stained crush preparation of tissue from the lesions can demonstrate the presence of Leishman bodies (amastigotes of Leishmania donovani).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. PCR for lepra bacilli:

 

  • PCR for Mycobacterium leprae is a highly sensitive technique for detecting leprosy bacilli but given the patient's geographic location and history suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis, it is not the most appropriate choice for this case.

 

Option C. Skin biopsy:

 

  • While a skin biopsy is generally the next step in cases suspicious for leprosy with a negative AFB smear, the patient's history and presentation are more suggestive of PKDL, a sequelae of leishmaniasis rather than leprosy.

 

Option D. Repeat slit-skin smear including nasal septum and earlobes:

 

  • This option would be more appropriate if leprosy were still being considered as a primary diagnosis.
  • However, the clinical context provided points toward PKDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient from an endemic area with a history suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis and presenting with hypopigmented macules negative for AFB, the most appropriate diagnostic step is a crush tissue preparation stained with Giemsa to detect Leishman bodies.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 33.50-33.51, 140.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1107, 1473

questions.text: Which of the following hair is NOT infested by Pthirus Pubis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scalp Hair

 

Option B.

 

  • Pthirus pubis usually does not infest scalp hair. Infestation of the scalp is generally caused by a different species called Pediculus Humanus Capitis, which causes Pediculosis Capitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pubic Hair:

 

  • Pthirus pubis, commonly known as crab louse or pubic louse, typically infests the hair in the pubic region. This is the most common site for an infestation.

 

Option C. Axillary Hair:

 

  • Pthirus pubis can also infest axillary hair. The body hair in the axillary region can provide a suitable environment for the lice to live and lay eggs.

 

Option D. Eyelashes:

 

  • Although less common, Pthirus pubis can infest eyelashes, where they are associated with a condition known as pthriasis Palpebrarum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pthirus pubis does not typically infest scalp hair, which is more commonly affected by Pediculus humanus capitis causing pediculosis capitis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 34.17, 34.16, 34.22,

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1507

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a rural area in India presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of persistent skin lesions. He was treated for visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-Azar) two years ago. On examination, he has multiple hypopigmented macules and nodules on his face, arms, and trunk. A skin biopsy reveals amastigotes within macrophages. What is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: Correct Answer: Option A:

  • Miltefosine is currently the treatment of choice for Post Kala Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) as per the latest guidelines.
  • It is an oral antileishmanial agent that is effective against leishmaniasis.
  • Miltefosine works by disrupting lipid metabolism and inducing apoptosis-like cell death in Leishmania parasites.
  • It offers the advantage of oral administration, high efficacy, and a favorable safety profile compared to injectable agents like amphotericin B.
  • Its inclusion in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) protocols highlights its central role in managing PKDL.

 

Other options:

Option B Betamethasone:

  • Betamethasone is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation in various dermatological conditions.
  • However, it does not have any antileishmanial activity and is therefore not effective in treating PKDL.

 

Option C Fluconazole:

  • Fluconazole is an antifungal agent used to treat fungal infections.
  • It has no efficacy against Leishmania parasites and is not used in the treatment of PKDL.

 

Option D Dapsone:

  • Dapsone is an antibiotic with anti-inflammatory properties, used in the treatment of leprosy and certain skin conditions.
  • It does not have antileishmanial properties and is not appropriate for treating PKDL.

 

Educational Objective:

  • The treatment of choice for Post Kala Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is Miltefosine

 

References:

Online references: https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/Doc/PKDL-Guidelines-220512.pdf

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Page no 33.51

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1476

questions.text: Topical or Intralesional Steroids are indicated in which type of Scabies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular:

 

Option B:

 

  • Nodular scabies is characterized by persistent nodules, often found in the groin or axillary regions, which can remain even after the infestation is treated.
  • These nodules are due to a hypersensitivity reaction to mite antigens and can be pruritic and uncomfortable.

 

The below image shows nodular scabies.

 

 

 

 

  • Topical or intralesional steroids are used to reduce inflammation and itching in these lesions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Animal:

 

  • Animal scabies, caused by mites that typically infest animals, may cause a self-limiting dermatitis in humans but is not typically treated with steroids, as it resolves when the human host is no longer in contact with the animal.

 

Option C. Infantile:

 

  • Infantile scabies presents similarly to adult scabies, but with a higher propensity for widespread involvement and pustular lesions.
  • The treatment is with Antiscabetic agents, and steroids are not typically used unless there is a significant inflammatory component.

 

Option D. Norwegian:

 

  • Norwegian, or crusted, scabies is a severe form of scabies with extensive crust formation and high mite load.
  • The mainstay of treatment is aggressive ant scabietic therapy, and steroids are not a primary treatment modality for the scabies itself, though they may be used to manage associated inflammatory skin reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Topical or intralesional steroids are indicated in nodular scabies to reduce the hypersensitivity reaction and inflammation associated with persistent nodules, alongside anti scabetic treatment.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 34.47

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1506

questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled boy was brought with large warty crusts on the trunk, hands & feet as shown below. Severe fissuring & scaling of the skin noted over the soles. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Norwegian Scabies

 

Option D.

 

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of Norwegian scabies or human crusted scabies.
  • Norwegian/crusted scabies/Hyperkeratotic scabies: Most severe type, millions of mites present but itching is less / absent.
  • Crusted scabies develops in people who do not have a strong enough immune response to the mite, allowing it to thrive. It is common type of scabies causing institutional breakouts. Because it was first described in Lepers of Norway, it is known as Norwegian.

 

Norwegian Scabies or Human Crusted or Hyperkeratotic Scabies is seen in:

 

  • Immunocompromised
  • Debilitated patients
  • Neurologic Disorders (Intellectually challenged, Dementia, Downs syndrome)
  • Organ Transplant Recipients
  • Hansen’s Disease
  • AIDS

 

Clinical images of Norwegian scabies:

 

 

 

  • The hands and feet develop large warty crusts.
  • The palms and soles may have thickened, irregularly fissures. Under the thickened and discolored nails, horny debris builds up.
  • The scalp, face, and seborrheic areas all exhibit erythema and scaling. Frequently, the itching will not be present.
  • The diagnosis is supported by scrapings teeming with eggs and mites.
  • Number of mites in scabies patients with normal itch response is 10-15 mites/person.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scabies Incognito:

 

  • This refers to atypical presentations of scabies that result from treatments with corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents.
  • The term "incognito" is used because the typical clinical features of scabies might be masked, making diagnosis challenging. While it might cause atypical skin changes, it doesn't usually present with the extensive crusting described in the case.

 

Option B. Animal Scabies:

 

  • Humans can be transiently infested with mites from animals, which cause a condition often referred to as "pseudo-scabies."
  • The itch mites from animals typically do not reproduce on human skin, so the infestation tends to be self-limited. The presentation is usually pruritic papules and not extensive crusting.

 

Option C. Nodular Scabies:

 

  • This variant presents with persistent pruritic nodules, often found on covered areas like the axilla or groin.
  • These nodules are an immunological reaction to the mites or their products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Norwegian scabies by its hallmark presentation of extensive crusting and scaling, particularly in patients with compromised immune systems or sensory deficits, as it require prompt and aggressive treatment to prevent outbreaks.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.42, 34.43, 34.45, 34.47
